This update allows IT administrators to configure passkey authentication policies at a granular level, enabling organizations to tailor authentication methods for different user groups. The rollout is set to occur globally from mid-October to mid-November 2025 and will simplify the authentication process by unifying credentials from hardware keys, computers, and mobile devices.

item.title: How CVE-2025-6018 and CVE-2025-6019 Enable Full Root Access on Linux
item.description: Vulnerable Product: openSUSE Leap 15, SUSE Linux Enterprise 15; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6018, CVE-2025-6019; Summary: Two newly discovered Local Privilege Escalation (LPE) vulnerabilities in Linux distributions allow attackers to chain low-level access into full root control. The first vulnerability manipulates environment variables during login, allowing remote attackers to impersonate local users and gain permission to perform actions reserved for physical users. The second vulnerability abuses XFS file system resizing to gain root access using the udisk daemon.

item.title: LogMeIn Remote Access Abused in Targeted System Compromise
item.description: This article describes a sophisticated cyberattack campaign that leverages LogMeIn Resolve remote access software to gain unauthorized control over user systems. The attack begins with a convincingly crafted invoice-themed spam email, designed to trick recipients into opening a malicious PDF attachment, which installs the remote access tool and grants attackers full remote access to the compromised system.

item.title: Jitter-Trap: New Method Uncovers Stealthy Beacon Communications
item.description: The article introduces Jitter-Trap, a detection technique that uses behavioral and network analysis to identify post-exploitation and command-and-control (C2) communication in cyberattacks. It leverages the randomness used by attackers to evade detection, turning it into a powerful detection tool.

item.title: Russian APT29 Exploits Gmail App Passwords to Bypass 2FA in Targeted Phishing Campaign
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google account feature - Application Specific Passwords (ASPs); CVE(s): None; Summary: Threat actors with suspected ties to Russia are using a novel social engineering tactic that takes advantage of Google's application specific passwords (ASPs) to gain access to victims' email accounts. The tactic involves building rapport with targets, sending benign phishing emails disguised as meeting invitations, and tricking them into sharing the ASP passcode.

item.title: CVE-2025-3248 in Langflow Exploited to Deploy Flodrix Botnet
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Langflow; CVE(s): CVE-2025-3248; Summary: A critical Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability in Langflow's /api/v1/validate/code endpoint allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary code directly on the server, granting remote control over the host. The vulnerability impacts Langflow versions prior to 1.3.0 and is particularly dangerous due to Langflow's popularity in cloud-hosted AI deployments.

item.title: Cisco AnyConnect VPN Flaw Allows Attackers to Launch DoS Attacks
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Cisco Meraki; CVE(s): CVE-2025-20271; Summary: The vulnerability stems from a variable initialization error that occurs when establishing SSL VPN sessions using client certificate authentication. Attackers can exploit this flaw by sending specially crafted HTTPS requests to affected devices, causing the Cisco AnyConnect VPN service to crash and restart, immediately disconnecting all active VPN users and forcing them to re-authenticate.

item.title: Ransomware Gang Busted by Authorities; Devices and Evidence Seized
item.description: Thai authorities dismantled a sophisticated criminal enterprise operating from the Antai Holiday Hotel in Pattaya, discovering a high-stakes gambling den and a ransomware cybercrime ring. The operation highlights the growing trend of cybercrime being intertwined with traditional organized crime, including gambling, money laundering, and identity theft.

item.title: Apache Traffic Server Vulnerability Allows DoS Attacks Through Memory Exhaustion
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Apache Software Foundation Apache Traffic Server; CVE(s): CVE-2025-49763; Summary: Attackers can exploit a flaw in the Edge Side Includes (ESI) plugin to trigger denial-of-service (DoS) attacks by exhausting server memory, affecting multiple versions of ATS 9.0.0 to 9.2.101 and 10.0.0 to 10.0.5.

item.title: Ryuk ransomware’s initial access expert extradited to the U.S.
item.description: A member of the Ryuk ransomware operation, who specialized in gaining initial access to corporate networks, has been extradited to the United States. The individual was arrested in April 2025 and is suspected of earning $150 million while active between 2018 and 2020.

item.title: Meta Adds Passkey Login Support to Facebook for Android and iOS Users
item.description: Meta Platforms is adding support for passkeys on Facebook, allowing users to securely sign in with biometrics or device lock PIN code. This passwordless authentication solution is resistant to guessing or theft by malicious websites and effective against phishing and password spraying attacks.

item.title: Open Next SSRF Flaw in Cloudflare Lets Hackers Fetch Data from Any Host
item.description: Vulnerable Product: @opennextjs/cloudflare; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6087; Summary: The @opennextjs/cloudflare package contains a critical Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) vulnerability that allows unauthenticated attackers to proxy arbitrary remote content through the vulnerable site's domain, posing risks of phishing, data exposure, and domain abuse.

item.title: Password Reset Link Poisoning Leads to Full Account Takeover
item.description: A critical vulnerability known as Password Reset Link Poisoning enables attackers to manipulate the domain in password reset links, redirecting users to malicious sites and capturing sensitive reset tokens. This allows for full account takeover, exposing web users and organizations to serious risks such as account takeover, phishing, and reputational damage.

item.title: New Linux Flaws Enable Full Root Access via PAM and Udisks Across Major Distributions
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Qualys PAM and libblockdev; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6018, CVE-2025-6019; Summary: Two local privilege escalation (LPE) flaws were discovered by Qualys that can be exploited to gain root privileges on machines running major Linux distributions. CVE-2025-6018 allows an unprivileged user to elevate to the "allow_active" user and call Polkit actions, while CVE-2025-6019 enables an "allow_active" user to gain full root privileges by chaining it with CVE-2025-6018.

item.title: DRAT V2: Updated DRAT Emerges in TAG-140’s Arsenal
item.description:
This article appears to be a cybersecurity analysis report on the DRAT V2 malware used by the TAG-140 group. The report provides an in-depth analysis of the malware's technical and operational details, including its command structure, C2 obfuscation techniques, and communication protocol.
The report highlights several key differences between the original DRAT and DRAT V2 variants, such as the use of different command naming conventions, changes to system information response formats, and modifications to C2 obfuscation patterns. The analysis also notes that while both versions use Base64 encoding for C2 information, DRAT V2 prepends additional strings to the IP address prior to encoding, which may serve as rudimentary integrity checks or prevent trivial decoding by analysts and automated tools.
The report provides several detection rules and guidelines for security teams to detect and monitor TAG-140 activity, including Snort rules for detecting outbound C2 communication, Sigma rules for detecting persistence via registry run keys, and YARA rules for detecting files containing strings associated with the BroaderAspect malware. The analysis concludes that while DRAT V2 exhibits limited use of defensive evasion or anti-analysis techniques, security teams should remain vigilant and anticipate continued experimentation with malware tooling and infection chains.

item.title: Pro-Israel hackers hit Iran's Nobitex exchange, burn $90M in crypto
item.description: The "Predatory Sparrow" hacking group claims to have stolen over $90 million in cryptocurrency from Nobitex, Iran's largest crypto exchange, and intentionally burnt the funds by sending them to vanity addresses. The attack is believed to be politically motivated, with ties to the IRGC and Iranian leadership.

item.title: Address bar shows hp.com. Browser displays scammers’ malicious text anyway.
item.description: The article discusses a scam that injects fake phone numbers into official websites through Google ads. Scammers buy ads with appended parameters that are not displayed in the ad itself, making it difficult for users to suspect anything is amiss. The injected phone number appears legitimate and can trick users into revealing personal or financial information.

item.title: North Korean hackers deepfake execs in Zoom call to spread Mac malware
item.description: Vulnerable Product: BlueNoroff; CVE(s): None; Summary: The North Korean BlueNoroff hacking group is using deepfakes to trick employees into installing custom malware on their macOS devices. The attack involves a fake Zoom meeting and the installation of an AppleScript file that downloads a secondary payload, which includes malicious binaries such as Telegram 2, Root Troy V4, a (InjectWithDyld), XScreen (keyboardd), and CryptoBot (airmond).

item.title: ZDI-25-408: PEAK-System Driver PCANFD_ADD_FILTERS Time-Of-Check Time-Of-Use Information Disclosure Vulnerability
item.description: Vulnerable Product: PEAK-System Driver PCANFD_ADD_FILTERS; CVE(s): CVE-2025-6217; Summary: This vulnerability allows local attackers to disclose sensitive information on affected installations of PEAK-System Driver. An attacker must first obtain the ability to execute low-privileged code on the target system in order to exploit this vulnerability, which is due to a lack of proper locking when performing operations on an object.

item.title: Chollima Hackers Target Windows and MacOS with New GolangGhost RAT Malware
item.description: The Famous Chollima group has launched a sophisticated remote access trojan (RAT) campaign targeting Windows and MacOS devices, with a focus on professionals in cryptocurrency and blockchain technologies. The attackers use a two-pronged strategy, creating fake job interview platforms to lure victims into executing malicious commands that download and launch the PylangGhost or GolangGhost variants.

item.title: AI Revolutionizes PLA Military Intelligence with Rapid Deployment Across Operations
item.description: The People's Liberation Army (PLA) of China is adopting generative artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance its military operations, using advanced large language models (LLMs) for data processing, intelligence analysis, and decision-making support. This integration poses risks such as hallucination issues, ideological bias, and counterintelligence concerns, highlighting the need for rigorous experimentation and outcome assessment to ensure effective application of AI tools.

item.title: Russia’s Digital Arsenal: The Strategic Use of Private Companies and Hacktivists in Cyber Operations
item.description: Russia's sophisticated cyber warfare strategy emerges as a calculated blend of state power and non-state agility, leveraging private companies, hacktivists, and criminal proxies to amplify its digital dominance. The strategy involves concentric rings with state agencies at the core and a diverse array of non-state actors, including private IT firms, hacktivist groups, and eCrime collectives, which offers Moscow cost efficiency, flexibility, and access to cutting-edge skills, but also risks unpredictability and blurs the line between state and non-state action.

item.title: A week with a "smart" car
item.description:
The article discusses the author's experience with advanced vehicle systems in a new car, highlighting issues with constant alerts and difficulty disabling features. It also touches on the importance of user experience and frictionless security tools.
FYSA: Cisco Talos has discovered that the North Korean-aligned threat actor Famous Chollima is targeting cryptocurrency and blockchain professionals through sophisticated phishing campaigns using Python-based malware (PylangGhost) and Golang-based variants. The campaign highlights the constant evolution of threat actors' tools, emphasizing the need for robust defenses and user education.
FYSA: AI scraping bots are breaking into libraries, archives, museums, and galleries, causing some collections to go offline. Additionally, a cybercriminal group leaked 7.4 million citizen records in Paraguay on the dark web, demanding $7.4 million.

item.title: Halo Security Honored with 2025 MSP Today Product of the Year Award
item.description: Halo Security's Attack Surface Management Platform has been named a 2025 MSP Today Product of the Year Award winner for its innovation, performance, and measurable impact on customers and partners alike. The platform enables organizations to discover, monitor, and secure their internet-facing assets, combining attacker-like discovery methods with ongoing security monitoring and vulnerability scanning.

item.title: Beware: Fake CAPTCHA Windows Stealthily Install LightPerlGirl Malware
item.description: A newly identified malware strain, LightPerlGirl, uses deceptive fake CAPTCHA popups to infiltrate systems. It propagates through a social engineering tactic called the ClickFix attack, bypassing traditional security measures and exploiting user interaction. The attack begins with a compromised legitimate website serving malicious JavaScript, which triggers a fake CAPTCHA popup, tricking users into executing an obfuscated PowerShell command.

item.title: New Malware Campaign Uses Cloudflare Tunnels to Deliver RATs via Phishing Chains
item.description:
The article describes a new campaign using Cloudflare Tunnel subdomains to host malicious payloads and deliver them via phishing emails. The attack starts with sending payment-themed emails bearing a link to a zipped document containing a Windows shortcut file, which activates the infection sequence. The payload is executed in memory, allowing for evasion of detection.
FYSA: None

item.title: Microsoft 365 to block file access via legacy auth protocols by default
item.description: This article does not mention a specific vulnerability. Instead, it discusses Microsoft's announcement to update security defaults for all Microsoft 365 tenants to block access to SharePoint, OneDrive, and Office files via legacy authentication protocols.

item.title: 'Stargazers' use fake Minecraft mods to steal player passwords
item.description:
A large-scale malware campaign targets Minecraft players by distributing malicious mods and cheats that infect Windows devices with info-stealers. The campaign uses GitHub as a distribution platform, disguising the malware as legitimate Minecraft content, and can steal credentials, authentication tokens, and cryptocurrency wallets.
Note: There is no specific vulnerability mentioned in this article, but rather a malicious campaign using social engineering tactics to spread malware to victims' devices.

item.title: 1,500+ Minecraft Players Infected by Java Malware Masquerading as Game Mods on GitHub
item.description:
The article describes a multi-stage malware campaign targeting Minecraft users, which employs a Java-based malware using a distribution-as-service (DaaS) offering called Stargazers Ghost Network. The campaign's end goal is to trick players into downloading a Minecraft mod from GitHub and deliver a .NET information stealer with comprehensive data theft capabilities.
FYSA: The article highlights the use of an illicit offering, the Stargazers Ghost Network, which makes use of thousands of GitHub accounts to set up tainted repositories that masquerade as cracked software and game cheats.

item.title: ChainLink Phishing: How Trusted Domains Become Threat Vectors
item.description: The article discusses the evolution of phishing attacks, specifically "ChainLink Phishing", which uses trusted infrastructure to funnel victims through a series of credible-looking prompts before harvesting credentials. It highlights how traditional defenses are insufficient against these attacks and emphasizes the need for real-time analysis of web pages and user interactions to effectively mitigate threats like zero-hour phishing.

item.title: CISA warns of attackers exploiting Linux flaw with PoC exploit
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Linux kernel's OverlayFS subsystem; CVE(s): CVE-2023-0386; Summary: A high-severity vulnerability (CVE-2023-0386) in the Linux kernel's OverlayFS subsystem allows attackers to gain root privileges. The flaw, caused by improper ownership management, was patched in January 2023 and publicly disclosed two months later. Multiple proof-of-concept exploits were shared on GitHub, making exploitation attempts easier.

item.title: Healthcare SaaS firm says data breach impacts 5.4 million patients
item.description: Episource, a healthcare services company, has reported a data breach that affected over 5 million people in the United States. The breach occurred between January 27 and February 6, 2025, when hackers accessed and exfiltrated sensitive health information, including full names, physical addresses, medical records, and social security numbers.

item.title: SuperCard Malware Hijacks Android Devices to Steal Payment Card Data and Relay it to Attackers
item.description: The article discusses the emergence of SuperCard, a malicious modification of the legitimate NFCGate program, which exploits Near Field Communication (NFC) traffic to intercept sensitive bank card data. The malware is distributed via a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) platform named SuperCard X and targets Android users globally, with recent attacks recorded in Russia.

item.title: Zyxel NWA50AX Pro Hit by N-Day Flaw Allowing Arbitrary File Deletion
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Zyxel NWA50AX Pro; CVE(s): CVE-2024-29974; Summary: The Zyxel NWA50AX Pro WiFi 6 access point contains an arbitrary file deletion vulnerability (CVE-2024-29974) that allows attackers to delete files without authentication by crafting a POST request with manipulated parameters. This can lead to further attacks, such as replacing configuration or password files, potentially causing privilege escalation or denial of service.

item.title: Hackers Exploit Transit Mode in Apple Pay and GPay to Steal Money
item.description: Vulnerable Product: Mobile Wallets (Apple Pay, Google Pay); CVE(s): None; Summary: The Express Transit mode in mobile wallets like Apple Pay and Google Pay allows for automatic charges without biometric checks or alerts, making it vulnerable to exploitation by hackers who can drain funds instantly and silently. Attackers can grab unlocked phones, mimic legitimate behavior, and exploit weak PINs to steal money.

item.title: Microsoft Enhances Office 365 Defender to Stop Email Bombing Campaigns
item.description: The article discusses a new feature called Mail Bombing Detection in Microsoft Office 365 Defender, designed to combat email bombing attacks by automatically identifying and blocking massive volumes of emails. This feature is enabled by default and does not require manual configuration, providing enhanced protection against email-based threats without additional administrative overhead.

item.title: MITRE and Splunk Expose Critical Vulnerabilities in Open Source GitHub Actions
item.description: Vulnerable Product: GitHub Actions; CVE(s): CVE-2025-47928; Summary: The GitHub Actions workflows of several high-profile open source projects were found to be vulnerable due to the misuse of the pull_request_target trigger. This vulnerability allows attackers to access sensitive secrets and high-privilege tokens, potentially leading to full repository takeovers. The vulnerability was exploited in projects like spotipy-dev/spotipy and MITRE's Cyber Analytics Repository (CAR).

item.title: RapperBot Botnet Surges with 50,000+ Attacks Targeting Network Edge Devices
item.description: Vulnerable Product: N/A; CVE(s): None; Summary: The RapperBot botnet has resurfaced with over 50,000 attacks targeting network edge devices, exploiting vulnerabilities in IoT devices such as routers, IP cameras, and other connected hardware. The botnet uses brute-force techniques and exploits known vulnerabilities to compromise devices, establishing persistence by downloading additional payloads and conducting DDoS attacks or serving as a gateway for further malicious activities.

item.title: DMV-Style Phishing Scams Target U.S. Citizens to Harvest Sensitive Information
item.description: A highly coordinated phishing campaign targeting U.S. citizens has been discovered, utilizing SMS phishing (smishing) and impersonating state Departments of Motor Vehicles (DMVs). The attack threatened license suspension or legal action and attempted to steal personal information by directing victims to fake DMV websites. The campaign is attributed to a China-based threat actor.

item.title: VMware Unveils Cloud Foundation 9.0 With AI and Next-Gen Workloads
item.description: VMware has announced the general availability of VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) 9.0, a private cloud technology designed to meet the demands of AI, data-intensive workloads, and modern enterprise operations. The new release offers a unified platform that merges the speed and flexibility of cloud with the performance, governance, and cost control required for on-premises environments.

item.description: Vulnerable Product: Google Chrome; CVE(s): None; Summary: The update addresses three high-severity vulnerabilities, including an integer overflow in V8 and a use-after-free in Profiler, which could allow attackers to execute arbitrary code, potentially leading to data theft or system compromise.
